How do I use search command in Factiva?

If you are a beginner and new to "Search Builder", you can refer to this guide on "How do I use search commands?" <https://smu.sharepoint.com/:b:/r/teams/library/Datasets/Other%20misc%20files/Factiva%20-%20How%20do%20I%20use%20search%20commands.pdf?csf=1&web=1&e=cy6Xg9> for more details. If you are looking for something more advance, there are many commands (aka as operators) available in Factiva that can help you with your complex search. You can refer to this "Search Builder Cheat Sheet & Quick Reference Guide" PDF <https://smu.sharepoint.com/:b:/r/teams/library/Datasets/Other%20misc%20files/Factiva%20-%20Search%20Builder%20Cheat%20Sheet%20%26%20Quick%20Reference%20Guide.pdf?csf=1&web=1&e=6uXZVC> for help.

Before you start to use the commands, it is good to understand how Factiva indexs each newspaper and their articles. Different papers use different way to index. There is no standard guide or cheat sheet for this; you have to go into each paper to find out.



From the newspaper source, there is a “Display Options” on top right corner (see image below). Click on it and select “Headline, Lead Paragraph, plus Indexing”. After that, you will be able to see a list of field labels. These labels will be useful when you do advance search.

Take the following newspapers for example, The Straits Times. The field labels used for this article are “CLM – Column”, “SE – Section”, “HD – Headline”, etc. Depending on what is your requirement, you may find these field label useful: “NS – Subject Code”, “RE – Region Code”, and  “SN – Source Name”.



 



#1 With these field labels, you can search for articles that only (1) appeared on front page and (2) are related to Singapore, (3) from The Straits Times. These are the commands to enter in the search box: SE=ST front page and RE=singp and SN=The Straits Times. You have to use exactly the same field name that appeared on the article. If you have selected "The Straits Times (Singapore)" under Source, you can omit SN=The Straits Times.



 

#2 Another example where you can search for (1) general news (2) in Singapore by using RE=singp and NS=gcat. If you have selected "The Straits Times (Singapore)" under Source, you can omit SN=The Straits Times.



 

You can also exclude certain type of article in your search result. Please refer to this PDF "How do I exclude certain types of articles" <https://smu.sharepoint.com/:b:/r/teams/library/Datasets/Other%20misc%20files/Factiva%20-%20How%20do%20I%20exclude%20certain%20types%20of%20articles.pdf?csf=1&web=1&e=qgbGCU> for more information on how it can be done.

Does SMU Libraries subscribe to any geocoding tools or services? e.g. Google Maps Geocoding API

Currently, SMU Libraries does not have a subscription for geocoding tools or API. There are a few geocoding tools that you can try, such as:

-Nominatim API <https://nominatim.org/> - Nominatim is an open-source address search engine that is developed and maintained by the OpenStreetMap community. It provides an API for geocoding that is free to use, but do take note on the usage policy of the API here <https://operations.osmfoundation.org/policies/nominatim/>. The policy imposes usage limit of "No heavy uses (an absolute maximum of 1 request per second)".
-Mapbox Geocoding API <https://docs.mapbox.com/api/search/geocoding/> - This API is free up to 100,000 request for Temporary Geocoding API (primarily used for searching). 
-Google Maps Geocoding API <https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/geocoding> - This API is on a pay-as-you-go <https://mapsplatform.google.com/pricing/#pricing-grid> pricing model, starting with USD 5 per month for every 1000 API request.


Most geocoding APIs out there should be able to do forward geocoding (converts addresses into geographic coordinates) and reverse geocoding (converts geographic coordinates to addresses).

More GIS tools and resources are available in this research guide <https://researchguides.smu.edu.sg/c.php?g=858553&p=6151205>.

How do I export my references and bibliography in MS Word to RIS/BibTeX?

If the references in Word was created using a Reference Manager tool like Zotero or Mendeley, the data is already in structured format and you can extract them using the free Reference Extractor tool <https://libanswers.caltech.edu/faq/204009> with almost 100% accuracy. 

Similarly if the references were created with Word's build-in reference function you can follow the procedure here to extract them.  <https://update.lib.berkeley.edu/2018/02/07/extracting-references-from-an-already-created-bibliography/>

However if the references were created manually by hand then you will need to use various tools to parse your plain-text bibliography or references into BibTex format that can then be imported to reference management software, Do note that these tools are not 100% accurate, depending on the citation style used.

 

Tool #1: AnyStyle.io <https://anystyle.io/>
-Make sure each of your reference entry starts in a new line
-Paste the bibliography into the text area.
-AnyStyle will parse the entries. If you notice any items labelled incorrectly, click on the item and click Assign label and choose the correct one.
-Save it as BibTex file
-Import the BibTex file to your Zotero library.

Tool #2: Scholarcy Reference Parser <https://www.scholarcy.com/reference-parser/>
-Make sure each of your reference entry starts in a new line, and click Convert
-The BibTex will appear on the field just below the text area. Select all of the contents of the BibTex and copy them (Ctrl + C)
-Go to Zotero and click on the folder where you want to import the entries
-Click File >> Import from Clipboard. This will paste the BibText entry from earlier to your Zotero library.

If these methods do not work well, or you need to do this process in bulk please approach the library for assistance.

I have a bibliography with a lot of articles that has no DOI. How do I find the DOI for those automatically?

There are several ways to find the DOIs in bulk:

Using Crossref's Simple Text Query <http://apps.crossref.org/SimpleTextQuery>

-Make sure that your bibliography is formatted correctly in any citation style (e.g. APA or MLA)
-List them in alphabetical order or presented as a numbered list.
-Paste them in Crossref's Simple Text Query <https://apps.crossref.org/SimpleTextQuery>. The tool allows up to 1000 references per submission.


Using Zotero's DOI Manager <https://github.com/bwiernik/zotero-shortdoi> Add-on

If you are already using Zotero to manage your references, you can use this add on to check for DOIs in just a few clicks.
-Download and install the add-on here <https://github.com/bwiernik/zotero-shortdoi>. The installation instructions are on the Readme page.
-The add-on will now automatically check for DOIs every time you import or add new references.
-Alternatively, you can also right-click on the reference entry >> Manage DOIs >> Get Long DOIs or Verify and Clean DOIs

Note:

-The add-on may not always find the DOI for every article. For such cases, the entry will be tagged under No DOI found so that you can manually search for them later in Crossref.
-Be sure to double check the DOI found to ensure that it corresponds to the correct article.

How do I find an article's DOI?

The Digital Object Identifier (DOI) of an article is usually listed on the PDF or the web page of the article. All DOI begin with 10, so it should look something like this: 10.7717/peerj.4903in URL format, it will look like this: https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.4903

If it is not mention anywhere in the PDF or the webpage, you can use Crossref <http://www.crossref.org/>'s "Search Metadata" search bar or Crossref's Free DOI Lookup <https://www.crossref.org/guestquery/> to find the DOI.

How do I find or search within the 50 Journals used in the FT Research Rank (FT50 Journals)?

The FT 50 Journals are the 50 journals used by the Financial Times (FT) in compiling the FT Business School Rankings <https://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/> which ranks Business Schools, including MBAs and EMBAs.

After the review in May 2016, the current list of 50 Journals can be found here <https://ft.com/content/3405a512-5cbb-11e1-8f1f-00144feabdc0>.

If you need to create a boolean search to search within all these 50 journals in Scopus the easiest way is to set up the search with ISSNs <https://gist.github.com/aarontaycheehsien/5916511d8657b693439eaed99244d3f7> rather than matching by source/publication titles because titles like “Operations Research” will match multiple journal titles such as  from Operations Research Letters and International Series In Operations Research And Management Science instead of just Operations Research, 

For doing the same in Web of Science refer to the complete guide here. <https://library.smu.edu.sg/topics-insights/creating-search-strategies-ft50>

What are some common ways to retrieve social media data e.g., Twitter?

Most social media have API that you can use to retrieve their data. Depending on the platform, you may need to apply for API Key or a developer account before you can use their API. Examples:

-Twitter API <https://developer.twitter.com/en/support/twitter-api#item0> - you will need a developer account and request for access <https://developer.twitter.com/en/apply-for-access>. 
-Reddit API <https://support.datacite.org/docs/api> - you will need a Reddit account and request for OAUTH Client ID <https://www.reddit.com/wiki/api>. 


If the platform does not provide an API (public or otherwise), you may want to consider web scraping. However, be sure to check that it is not against the website' terms and conditions to do so. Ensure that you also observe the following etiquette of web scraping: 

-Only save the data that you absolutely need 
-Request data at a reasonable rate 
-Include user agent string in your API calls that provides way to contact you  
-Respect the data provenance, do not claim them as yours 


(source: Ethics in Web Scraping <https://towardsdatascience.com/ethics-in-web-scraping-b96b18136f01>)

Why use API? What's the benefit of using API over the database's web interface?

Sure, some databases have a web interface where you can specify your requirements and then download the data in excel, CSV, or other formats. However, these web interfaces often impose a download limit or may not provide the filters you needed (e.g. you want to specify a date range, but the interface doesn't offer this). If you're working with a large amount of data, the resulting download file can be large and, therefore, slow to open and process. Sometimes, you may need to manually repeat the process and download multiple files, which can get tedious.  

Using API is helpful if you work with a large amount of data, as you can automate the download/retrieval process.
Given a student's academic related query or question, you will provide helpful information and resources as a librarian chatbot.
What is an API?

API stands for Application Programming Interface. Essentially, it’s a standardized method that enables online software/services to communicate with each other by way of exchanging data. 

 

APIs are used in many ways, such as adding new data on a website through another (e.g. automatically tweet a new blog post), retrieving data from publicly open data repositories, or updating contents in another website. In research and academia, however, data retrieval is the most common usage of API. Generally, you will need some knowledge of programming (e.g. R or Python) to use API.

 

To illustrate, API is quite like the self-service kiosks that we sometimes see in cafes or restaurants: 
-We use the self-service kiosk to send our order (request).
-We also make payment and provide other details required by the kiosk (API key/authentication key). 
-The restaurant processes our order and then pass it to us (response).

What are the useful mnemonics in EIKON?

There are many useful mnemonics in EIKON, some examples are:

-SRCH - Search: Find content and functionality using EIKON search.
-POLLS - Reuters Polls (Forecast): Discover all forecast data available from Reuters Poll.
-INDUS - Industry: Industry information such as news, events, research and key metrics.
-SCREENER - Screener: Screen public and private companies using a series of criteria.
-STARMINE - Starmine Overview: Starmine overview is a centralized application for learning more about Starmine models. 
-ECOP - Economic Indicator Polls: Monitor forecast of economic indicators based on the results from Reuters Polls. 
-FLOWS - Global Funds Flow:Explore and generate reports for Global Funds Flow.
-TRTR - Total returns: Perform total returns calculations, access total return chart and P&L analysis for multiple instruments. 
-IRPR - Interest rate probability: View interest rate probabilities for a number of different countries, including meeting dates, implied rates and probable actions.
-ALLO - This tool utilizes the classic Markowitz mean-variance analysis as well as Black-Litterman to derive the expected asset class returns.

Can I edit or delete my data?

Please note that you can only delete private items. 

If you need to delete a public item, this needs to be done by a system administrator. Please see I’ve accidentally set my data to public, what should I do <https://libfaq.smu.edu.sg/faq/264497>?

Private items

Private items can be edited without creating a new version. Remember to click save changes after making edits. 

You may also delete the entire item by scrolling to the bottom of the metadata form and click delete item. 

Public items

To edit a public item head to My data, click on the edit pen (this will become visible when you mouse over the item) that will then bring up the metadata form.

For public items, changes to the metadata field or the file itself will trigger a new version but the DOI remains the same. If you wish to change the file(s), you will first have to delete the existing file, to do this:

1. Scroll up the metadata form to where the file was uploaded 

2. Hover over the tick so that the delete button appears and click delete 

3. You can then drag and drop a new file 

4. Click save changes to save privately only, or click save changes and tick the publish checkbox in order to publish a new version. Click here <https://libfaq.smu.edu.sg/faq/264480> for more information about version control on SMU RDR.

I've accidentally set my data to public, what should I do?

-item DOI and title
-reason


A system administrator will assist to unpublish your data. It will become a draft record and no longer publicly available. If you later republish the item, it will retain the same DOI that the originally published item had.

How can I edit my data that has been made public? How does version control work?

Edit public data

Once logged in, find the published item to be edited under My data. Place your cursor on the item, and a pencil icon will appear on the far right. Clicking on this icon allows you to make changes to this item.

After making the necessary changes, you can save the record for editing later, or publish a new version of the record by ticking the box ‘Publish changes’, then click on the ‘Save changes’ button. The status of the record will become 'Under review' and the new version will be publicly available once approved. 

Version control on SMU RDR

Figshare supports versioning for both items and collections. Because projects are a continuous piece of work with a start date and finish date they are not candidates for versioning. 

There are a couple of changes that would trigger versioning. These rules are a bit different between items and collections. 

Items

When editing a public item, the following actions will trigger versioning when saving publicly: 

-Modifying the title 
-Add/edit/remove author/s 
-Adding new files 
-Removing files 
-Replacing files 
-Removing confidentiality from files 
-Removing the metadata only flag and uploading files 
-Replacing the link associated with a linked item 


Collections

Provided it is a public figshare collection, the following actions will trigger versioning, when saving publicly: 

-Modifying the title 
-Adding new items 
-Removing items 
-Replacing items 
-Add/edit/remove author/s 
-Upgrading the item’s version linked to the collection


After you have published a new version, the previous version(s) remains accessible via a drop-down menu. You need to contact library@smu.edu.sg <mailto:library@smu.edu.sg> if you wish to remove earlier versions. 

 

How are versions connected to DOI’s?

Every item or collection version has a DOI. 

Every Figshare item or collection has a base DOI. This DOI can be found by removing the version suffix from the DOI presented under Cite.

The base DOI always points to the latest public version.

For example, the base DOI of the item in the image above is: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.2066037 and it will point to the latest version, which at the moment is 17.

Each of the versions have their own DOI and can be cited independently. The version DOI is created from the base DOI by adding the v<x> suffix, where x is the version number.

What does it mean to 'Make files confidential'?

'Make files confidential' on SMU RDR allows you to publish a open record about your data but hide the actual data files. It allows other researchers to find your data and they could contact you to request for the data.

Please note that Make file(s) confidential is just a feature to hide your files from public view. It does not imply that you can upload confidential information to the repository.

How much storage space do I get? Can I request for more?

All SMU users are given 100GB individual storage for their individual dataset records. If you use Projects in SMU RDR, each Project will be given 100GB project storage and will not consume your individual quota. 

You may request for more storage space if needed. It will be subject to review and approval by the system administrator.

What is 'reserve a DOI'? How will it be useful for me?

In a draft record, clicking on 'Reserve Digital Object Identifier' creates a DOI that is inactive and reserved for your item. It will only become active when you publish the record in SMU RDR. 

You can include the reserved DOI in a paper or provide it to the publisher without having to publish the dataset. You can publish the record or make your data open when you are ready to do so.

What is a DOI? Why should I get a DOI for my dataset?

Digital Object Identifier (DOI) is a persistent unique identifier widely used for journal articles and datasets. Similar to how passport number can be used to identify a person, a DOI is used to uniquely identify a paper or dataset.

You should get a DOI for your dataset using SMU RDR because:

-DOIs offers a stable and persistent link to your dataset over the long run
-DOIs more reliable compared to URLs which easily become broken links
-DOIs allow citations to your data to be tracked to demonstrate impact


All published datasets in RDR will automatically receive a DOI from DataCite. For unpublished records, you may reserve a DOI which will become activated upon publishing the record.

How can I modify uploaded files in SMU RDR?

You can modify or replace the uploaded files of any draft or published record. 

If you make changes to the files of a published data record, a new version will be created while earlier versions remain accessible. 

You cannot edit files within your Internet browser like what you do in Google Docs. In order to modify a file, it must be downloaded, modified and re-uploaded to SMU RDR.
Given a student's academic related query or question, you will provide helpful information and resources as a librarian chatbot.
What file formats does SMU RDR accept?

SMU RDR does not restrict on file formats. 

However, to facilitate long-term accessibility and preservation, you are encouraged to use non-proprietary and open formats as much as possible. If data is in the format of a proprietary software, it may not be readable in the future when the software is no longer available.  

Examples of proprietary formats: .psd, .xlsx
Examples of non-proprietary formats:  .tiff, .txt,.csv

What is the difference between conference proceedings article and conference paper in IRIS?

A conference proceedings article is published in the proceedings of a conference and the proceedings can be found online or in physical format. E.g. ACM Symposium on Information, Computer and Communications Security found on ACM Digital Library <http://dl.acm.org/>, Innovative Applications of Artificial Intelligence Conference found on www.AAAI.org <http://www.AAAI.org>, Academy of Management Proceedings found on proceedings.aom.org <http://proceedings.aom.org/>.

A conference paper is presented at the conference but there is no published proceedings. E.g. INFORMS International Conference, Strategic Management Society Conference.

In IRIS, what is Intellectual Contribution and which option should I choose?

The field for Intellectual Contribution is mainly for AACSB reporting and is relevant for LKCSB and SOA. Other schools can choose to use it or select Not Applicable.

Options are Basic or Discovery Scholarship; Applied or Integration/Application Scholarship; Teaching and Learning Scholarship.

If your publication is about teaching and learning, please select Teaching and Learning Scholarship.

Definitions:
-Basic or Discovery Scholarship that generates and communicates new knowledge and understanding and/or development of new methods. Intellectual contributions in this category are normally intended to impact the theory, knowledge, and/or practice of business and management.

-Applied or Integration/Application Scholarship that synthesizes new understandings or interpretations of knowledge or technology; develops new technologies, processes, tools, or uses; and/or refines, develops, or advances new methods based on existing knowledge. Intellectual contributions in this category are normally intended to impact the practice of business and management.

-Teaching and Learning Scholarship that develops and advances new understandings, insights, and teaching content and methods that impact learning behavior. Intellectual contributions in this category are normally intended to impact the teaching of business and management.

Source: AACSB. 2013, April 8. Eligibility Procedures and Accreditation Standards for Business Accreditation.

What am I searching in the library search box?

Everything: The entire SMU Libraries collection (e.g books, videos, ebooks, journal titles) as well as a massive index of journal articles, book chapters, conference proceedings and other content. Can I use Boolean Operators, phrase searching, truncation etc in the Library Search?

The new library search supports the usual Boolean Operators, phrase searching and truncation functions.

Please use the following Boolean Operators in CAPS to get appropriate results

-AND
-OR
-NOT


The search  assumes that you are searching for all the words you type unless OR or NOT are specified between the words and phrases.

The search also supports

-phrase searching with double quotes - eg. "Credit Risk" to look for the exact phrase.
-Truncation with  asterisk - or * e.g. manag* to look for management, managing, manager etc.
-Single wildcard with question mark or ? - e.g wom?n to look for woman or women.


The library search does not support asterisks or wildcard characters at the beginning of a word and will ignore it. e.g *aying or ?saying will be searched as aying.

Why should I submit my full text articles to InK?

The global scholarly community is moving towards open access and SMU has an Open Access Policy <https://library.smu.edu.sg/sites/default/files/library/pdf/smuopenaccesspolicy_24102013.pdf> with effect from 24 October 2013. Uploading the full text PDFs of your publications into InK will make your publications easily accessible and freely available to everyone which will enhance the visibility of your research.

When your full text PDFs are available in InK, you will receive a monthly report via email and access to your personal Author Dashboard. The Author Dashboard enables you to view download counts, search terms used by others to find your work and institutions from which users have accessed your work.

Why does it benefit me to put my research works in InK?

InK is crawled by major search engines like Google and Google Scholar and the metadata in InK are harvested by sites like BASE, OAIster and OpenDOAR. Full text publications in InK are also part of the Digital Commons Network which brings together open access full-text scholarly articles from hundreds of universities and colleges worldwide. This helps others discover your research works, thus increasing the likelihood of them being cited.

What type of content or materials can I find in InK?

InK <https://ink.library.smu.edu.sg/>, INstitutional Knowledge at SMU is the institutional repository and archives of the Singapore Management University. InK acquires, organizes and provides access to the research and scholarly works of the SMU community. Collections in InK include journal articles, conference proceedings, books, book chapters, reports, working papers, and other research works including the dissertations and theses of postgraduate students and a collection of print and video teaching cases. InK also houses the University Heritage Collection which includes the SMU oral history interviews <https://ink.library.smu.edu.sg/smu_oh/> from and the SMU Image Gallery <https://ink.library.smu.edu.sg/heritage_gallery/>.

What is InK?

InK <https://ink.library.smu.edu.sg/> (Institutional Knowledge@ SMU) is the institutional repository and archives of SMU. As the institutional repository, InK acquires, organizes and provides access to the research and scholarly works of SMU faculty and postgraduate students. InK also serves as the university archives providing access to significant, historical records pertaining to the university.

InK also has a Faculty Gallery where the profiles of faculty at SMU and their works are featured. Contact the Library <mailto:library@smu.edu.sg?subject=InK%20query> for further help.

What is the difference between using the default library search box and Databases?

Use the default library search box to do a keyword search across the Library catalogue and multiple databases at one time. This is especially useful when you are researching a broad topic and you want to find both books and articles and are not sure which databases would be relevant. 

Use Databases to locate a specific resource to find relevant articles or data on your research topic. You can start by typing the database name, or browse by subject or by alphabet.

What type of materials cannot be provided via Document Delivery Services?

The type of materials that cannot be provided via Document Delivery Service are as follows.
-Articles not intended for teaching, learning and research. For non-academic staff, the articles required must be related to their area of work as well.
-Articles for commercial use
-Articles that exceed the copying limit of 1 article per issue per volume of a journal, 1 chapter or 10% (non-chapter) of a book
-Articles that violate the restrictions imposed by publishers, the source library or the local copyright law of the source library
-Articles used in course readings
-Materials which are not available for loan in libraries (e.g. Case studies)

What type of materials cannot be provided through Interlibrary Loan?

The following materials cannot be provided via interlibrary loan sources.

 

- Materials which are not for the purposes of teaching, learning and research. For non-academic staff, the material required must be related to their area of work as well.


 


- Materials in the our library’s collection (unless it is missing from the collection or is required urgently by faculty for research or teaching)



 

- Materials in the exclusion list of lending libraries (example of items in exclusion list are Multi-media & AV, thesis, rare collection, recently published books, Reference, Reserved Book/Reading (RBR), all journals and Microform collection)



 

- Material which are not available for loan or circulation within a library (e.g. case studies).




 


- Materials which are not available in local libraries and can be purchased within a week, for a price equal to or lower than the budget defined by the library.




 


- AV or media item (e.g. CD, DVD)




 


- Material that has been requested by the user before. Please recommend resources to be added to the library’s collection instead of repeatedly requesting them through ILL or document delivery service. Exception would be out of print items.




 


- Course Readings (faculty must ensure that their readings are available in the library’s collection or obtain the necessary copyright clearance to distribute their readings to students)

How long does it take the library to produce a course pack or e-reserves?

If the course readings have no copyright issues, the lead-time will be approximately 3 weeks. Processing time may take as long as 2 months for readings which require copyright clearance or the payment of copyright fees. During the first 4 weeks of the term, the response time of Course Support Services will be slower as staff will be engaged in course pack sales. Course reading request is processed on a first-come-first serve basis. Hence, please submit your request early to ensure that the readings can be prepared and made available before the start of the Term.

How does the library help faculty distribute course readings to students?

The library offers faculty an online course reading list service available in eLearn (see pictorial guide <http://researchguides.smu.edu.sg/readinglists>) where faculty can populate the reading list by pulling in existing books/articles from the library's collection, request library to purchase new titles/scan book chapters, upload own materials, or paste links to free resources online.

For scan books chapters the library will do a copyright check to see if the title is covered under CLASS before uploading the scanned reading.

The library also provides course pack services (students will need to purchase the course pack). A course pack is a compilation of case studies for students in hardcopy.

Students may print one copy for their personal use. However, please note that links cannot be provided for articles from Harvard Business Review. Hardcopy course pack will be sold to students during the first 2 weeks of each term.

Are all the materials on the CLASS publisher list covered in the agreement?

No. Please note the following:

(1) We cannot copy certain elements of an article/book if the copyright is not owned by the CLASS author/publisher e.g. case studies in the book, diagrams and photos within an article, where the copyright is owned by an

How do I go about distributing a material from a CLASS author/publisher?

The following conditions must be met before distributing the material.

a) The article copied are within copying limit of 1 article, 1 chapter or 10%(non-chapter) 

b) The copyright of the book and journal belongs to a publisher represented by CLASS. The list of CLASS publisher can be found in the link as follows. In addition, there should not be any 3rd party pictures, tables or extracts in the article.

https://intranet.smu.edu.sg/library/training/CSS/CLASS_Publisher_List.pdf

c) Copyright forms must be completed and submitted to Course Support Services, Li Ka Shing Library. This is done online through the link as follows.

https://intranet.smu.edu.sg/apps/L1SS/CRSearch.aspx?module=CR

d) The following notation must be stamp on the first page of the master copy.

"Copy made on behalf of Singapore Management University on <date>"

" No further reproduction allowed"

The date of the notation should tally with the date when the copyright form is submitted. The General Office of each School has a stamp of the notation. The notation can be stamped to the master copy before photocopying. Each faculty is responsible for ensuring that the distributed copies bear the notation.

What is the CLASS agreement?

CLASS stands for Copyright Licensing and Administration Society of Singapore Ltd, an organization which represents authors and publishers around the world and collects copyright licence fees for them. SMU has prepaid the copyright fees and signed an agreement with CLASS which allows faculty to photocopy and distribute materials belonging to their authors or publishers for teaching purposes. Faculy may distribute materials that falls within the copying limit when copying CLASS materials without further copyright clearance. However, the CLASS agreement requires all copying to be recorded. Hence, copyright forms must be filled and submitted to Course Support Services, Li Ka Shing Library. This can be done online via the link as follows.

https://intranet.smu.edu.sg/apps/L1SS/CRSearch.aspx?module=CR

The CLASS agreement covers only the undergraduate and postgradute (by coursework) programs. It is not applicable to executrive education programs. Please contact the Legal Office to verify if your program is covered in the CLASS agreement.

When do I need to seek copyright clearance for distributing a material in my class?

You will need to seek copyright clearance or pay the copyright fees when distributing any material in class, even if the material is copied within the copying limit of 1 article, 1 chapter or 10% (non-chapters). In the case of materials whose copyright is owned by publishers respresented by copyright licensing and Administration Society of Singapore Ltd (CLASS), the copyright fee is paid in advance by SMU for all undergraduate and postgraduate programmes (by coursework). Hence, faculty may distribute CLASS materials within copying limit without further payment. Please contact the library for further clarification if necessary.

Can I download or export Factiva data to EndNote (for Mac users)?

Yes, you can. Please use the Firefox browser when accessing Factiva. Here are the steps:
-Download the below attached Factiva Filter for Mac (Factiva_Modified.enf) and save it in Finder > Applications > EndNote X4 > Filters. Once you have the filter ready, you can proceed with Factiva search



-Locate the articles that you want to download/export, place a tick in the box near the headlines
-From the "Display Options" drop down menu on the right, choose "Full article/report plus indexing"



-Click "Format for Saving" button and choose "Article Format"

-Go back to your EndNote library and go to File > Import
-Browse and locate your .txt file
-Under "Import Options", choose "Factiva_Modified" (Go to Other Filters first if you couldn't locate Factiva_modified in the first drop down)
-Click "Import"



-Remember to clean up the record, if necessary.

What should I do if I want EndNote to render only in-text citation and footnotes (without reference list)?

You need to create a new/copied citation style in EndNote.
-Go to EndNote > Edit > Output Styles > Open Style Manager.
-Select the style that you wish to use and click Edit (e.g. Chicago 15th A).
-Go to Footnotes > Templates and remove the tick from the box "Include citations in bibliography"
-Save this style (File > Save As). You need to give it a different name (e.g. Chicago 15th A My Copy)
-Use this style for your paper

What does item's status e.g "In Process", "On holdshelf", "Use in lib", "Trace", "Show copies on order" mean?

Check the status of an item to see if it is available for loan.

-IN PROCESS: the item is in the library, pending physical processing
-ON HOLDSHELF: Item awaiting collection at Services Desk
-USE IN LIB: item is for use within the library only
-TRACE: the item is missing and the library is searching for the item
-SHOW COPIES ON ORDER: the item has been ordered but not received yet
-HOLDS : the item has been requested/reserved


 

Click here <http://researchguides.smu.edu.sg/content.php?pid=115443&sid=997272#4021896> for a list of different status.

Where can I find the members or constituents of an equity index?

The index members can be found in Bloomberg or Datastream.

For Bloomberg, after you have keyed in the Bloomberg index ticker, say SPX Index for S&P 500, enter MEMB <GO>.  Edit the date if you are looking for historical members.  Note a different ticker could be used for historical members, click DES <GO> for the index subscription.

Alternatively, you can use Bloomberg formula in Excel to retrieve the members.  Here is the formula for your reference:
 
=BDS("SPX Index","INDX_MWEIGHT_HIST","END_DATE_OVERRIDE=20020207")
Syntax: =BDS(ticker, field, overriding field=YYYYMMDD)


In Datastream, you can do a Criteria Search or use the Equity Indices Explorer to browse for the equity index, S&P 500 Composite, click on the arrow next to the mnemonic, S&PCOMP, select Display Constituent Equities

Where can I find Datamonitor Industry Reports?

Try the following databases:

Business Source Complete <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:Everything:SMU_ALMA6141637050002601>: The coverage includes management, economics, finance, accounting, and international business. It also has country economic reports from Global Insight and ICON Group, with Datamonitor industry and market research reports plus profiles for 10,000 companies. 

Marketline Advantage <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:BooksandVideos:SMU_ALMA6141635800002601>: <http://catalogue.library.smu.edu.sg/record=e1000074~S1> The content includes case studies, reports on countries, industries and companies, company news and financial deals. The Country Statistics database provides historical and forecasted macro/socio-economic and demographic data. The Market Data Analytics database contains data on various fast-moving consumer goods and includes brand share, company share, distribution channels, consumer graphics and market value/volume.

OneSource <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:BooksandVideos:SMU_ALMA6141635660002601>: This database contains profiles of 230,000 global and 363,000 Asian Pacific public and private companies. It houses thousands of company profiles, industry information, news, financials and executive profiles.

EMIS (Emerging Market Information Service) <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:BooksandVideos:SMU_ALMA6141636160002601>: Access this database for company and industry information, macroeconomic analysis, financial markets data and news for over 70 countries in Asia, Australia, Europe, Latin America, Africa & the Middle East. Includes some information on private companies. Many news sources are in the local language

S&P Capital IQ <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:BooksandVideos:SMU_ALMA6141633550002601>: S&P Capital IQ is a product of Standard & Poor's. It provides a web-based platform that has private and public company information, executive profiles, industry analysis, basic commodities information, economic data, historical and future estimates, and a function to create lists of companies/people using various criteria.

What is a Research Consultation?

A research consultation is a service provided by the library in which a research librarian guides users on a specific topic in a one-on-one or a small group format. A consultation is especially useful when the research topic is complex or the user has limited experience in using library resources.

Email library@smu.edu.sg <mailto:library@smu.edu.sg> to ask for an appointment and give detailed information about your research question/topic.

Where can I obtain weighted average cost of capital (WACC)?

You can find WACC from Capital IQ Excel Plug-in. From the +WACC template within the Excel Plug-in, navigate the Capital IQ Menu, choose Templates, and then select the Valuation option.

If the template does not appear here, select the "Get/Update Templates" option and choose the Valuation option to locate the +WACC template to download.

 

In Bloomberg, enter the ticker, followed by WACC <GO>. For e.g. enter MSFT US EQUITY WACC <GO>. You will be able to see the historical chart at the bottom left hand corner of the screen. Click on Chart >Copy Data to clipboard, and paste this onto an Excel sheet.

In the "Cost of Capital" section, you can view the breakdowns for cost of equity, cost of debt, cost of preferred equity, and the weights associated with each cost. Click any section to see detailed calculation components.

 

From EIKON Excel plug-in, use TR.WACC to get the weighted average capital cost. Use this formula (e.g. AAPL.O, as the sample company): 

=TR("AAPL.O","TR.WACC","CH=Fd RH=IN",B3)

How to get the persistent link for articles from Science Direct?

Science Direct uses a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) to provide a persistent link for its articles.



In addition to the Library proxy prefix, another URL has to be added to the DOI in order to provide access.

To create persistent links to articles in ScienceDirect, follow these steps:



-
Select the article from the result list by clicking on the title of the article





-
Find the DOI at the top of the page on the left. It will look something like this: 10.1016/S0167-2681(02)00178-6
Make sure you omit the "doi:" before the number.





 

 









-
Add the DOI to the following prefix: http://libproxy.smu.edu.sg/login?url=http://dx.doi.org/





The persistent link you provide will have the following format:

http://libproxy.smu.edu.sg/login?url=         http://dx.doi.org/         10.1016/S0167-2681(02)00178-6

Library Proxy Prefix                                         DOI Prefix                     DOI

What is "#NA limit" error encountered when downloading Bloomberg data to Excel?

#NA limit error occurs when the monthly data download limit has been reached for that particular Bloomberg terminal (not based on account). The limit will be reset on the first or second day of a new month. More details on data limit from here <https://guides.library.columbia.edu/bloomberg/downloadlimit>.

 

For Investment Studio, please use another Bloomberg terminal if you encounter this error.

Optional: You can run a API diagnostics test to check if the monthly data limit has reached.

-From the desktop or Windows Start key, look under Bloomberg folder, click API Environment Diagnostics 


          

1. Click Start under Diagnostic Check. 

2. Click Repair.

3. Under Authentication, error message will show "Data request failed with error". The API data job has failed.

Bloomberg has blocked the Excel data access for the individual terminal. Kindly note the monthly data limit is tied to individual terminal and not individual account ID.



 

 

For Bloomberg Anywhere accounts, you can run similar Bloomberg API test using TTST terminal test function. 

1) Enter TTST terminal test function in the command bar.

2) Select the language to continue with the test. Please click English.

3) Please launch the test, and select Bloomberg API.

4) Click 'Download' to download the Excel spreadsheet

5) When the cell data showed many cell value with #N/A, or #ERROR, this meant the monthly data limit has reached for this Bloomberg Account SID (subscription ID) account.

Please try to logoff and login to another account.

What is a Bloomberg ticker?

A Bloomberg ticker is a string of characters or numbers to identify a company or entity uniquely in Bloomberg.

Equity Bloomberg ticker is made up of 3 parts:
-Bloomberg ticker
-Exchange code
-Market Sector [Equity]

Example:
Singapore Airlines is SIA SP EQUITY.
Schroder Singapore Trust is SCHSNGI SP EQUITY.

Index Bloomberg ticker consists of:
-Bloomberg ticker
-Market Sector [Index]

Example: Hang Seng Index is HSI INDEX.

What is RIC (Reuters Instrument Code)?

It is a unique identifier for Reuters data used to represent a financial instrument.

An equity RIC is made up of stock code and exchange identifier to show where it is traded. 

For example, TSLA.O is Tesla Inc.'s RIC.

What are the Bloomberg formulas that I can use in Excel spreadsheet?

Bloomberg Data Point (BDP)

BDP formulas provide current data and descriptive real-time/streaming data.

Formula: =BDP(security ticker, field)
Example: =BDP("SIA SP Equity", "px_last")

Bloomberg Data History (BDH)

BDH formulas provide historical end-of-day and historical intra-day data.

Formula: =BDH(security, field(s), start date, end date)
Example: =BDH("SIA SP Equity","px_last", "12/30/2008", "12/30/2009")

Bloomberg Data Set (BDS)

BDS formulas gives multi-cells of data such as company description, index members' weightage, top holders, etc.

Formula: =BDS(ticker, field)
Example: =BDS(PSI20 Index, indx mweight, "cols=2;rows=20")

For template with formulas set up, enter API <GO> > click Sample Spreadsheet > choose Tutorials > Bloomberg API.
Given a student's academic related query or question, you will provide helpful information and resources as a librarian chatbot.

How do I locate Appeal Cases (AC) cases?

AC stands for Appeal Cases and is part of 'The Law Reports' of England and Wales. 

The following databases provide access. 

 

LawNet  <http://libproxy.smu.edu.sg/login?url=http://edu.lawnet.com.sg>

The Law Reports are available in LawNet. 
1) Select “English Cases” under the “Cases” Section on the home page. 
2) Enter the case name e.g. “Donoghue v Stevenson” or the case citation “1932 AC 562”, to search. 

 

Lexis Advance <https://advance-lexis-com.libproxy.smu.edu.sg/sourceselection/?pdmfid=1522471&crid=01063348-d245-420a-92fe-6cc8f0a4e2a3&pdsearchdisplaytext=UK+Cases&pdicsfeatureid=op1517131&ecomp=5cdLk&earg=sp1&prid=fbaba3f1-1f06-4260-883f-bb7291baa286>

Select "UK" and search by using citation or case name. 

 
Westlaw <https://1-next-westlaw-com.libproxy.smu.edu.sg/Search/Home.html?rs=IWLN1.0&vr=3.0&sp=smu-1000&forcecdn=false&bhskip=1&transitionType=Default&contextData=(sc.Default)>

1) Under “All Content”, select “International Materials”

2) Select “United Kingdom”

3) Under “Content Types”, select “Cases”

4) Enter the citation or case name and search

How can I print screen on white background at the Bloomberg terminal?

-
After you have logon to the Bloomberg terminal, go to the Terminal tab at the top
-
In Print Setup, choose Print B On W
-
In Terminal Defaults under Display, choose Black on White
-
Next click on Export tab, select Save Screen as File.
-
In the pop-up window, enter the file name, and in the Save as type field, select GIF.  (Save file in GIF format)
-
(Repeat steps 1 and 2 on each screen if the list has more than one page)
-
Email the GIF files to yourself or save them in a thumb drive.
-
Print the files at any printer/computer. 
-
Otherwise, map printer to the Bloomberg terminal & press Print Screen.

How do I install the Bloomberg Excel Add-in?

Bloomberg Excel plug-in does not install by default and it is tied to individual account. You can trigger the installation by using the following steps:

-From Windows button, look for "Bloomberg" > "API Environment Diagnostics", OR
-Look for "API Environment Diagnostics" icon on the Windows desktop, OR
-Look for "Bloomberg" folder on the Windows desktop, then double click on "API Environment Diagnostics"
-Once "API Environment Diagnostics" is launched, click "Start" to begin
-After the diagnostics is completed, click "Repair"
-When the "Repair" is done, check the result under "Bloomberg Excel Addin". You should see green tick. If it doesn't, please make sure all Microsoft products are closed. Then repeat last three steps again. If the red crosses are still showing, try another terminal and report the issue to libser@smu.edu.sg

How do I book campus / library facilities?

Campus/ Library facilities can be booked using the Resource Booking System

The Resource Booking System allows you to search for available facilities by building and facility name.

The system has a ‘Multiple Facilities with One Booking’ feature that allows you to book more than one facility for a given time slot using just one booking form.

The “Recurrent Booking” feature within the system allows you to Block-book the facilities you want. You can also save the recurrence patterns like start times, end times, recurrence frequencies etc, and use them as templates for future bookings.

Click here <https://intranet.smu.edu.sg/apps/efm/FacilitiesBookingHelp.htm> to view help.

How can I reserve an item that has been borrowed by someone else?

Books, DVDs, etc. which are already borrowed by another user can be requested, with the exception of items in Reserves, Special Collections or 3-day loans.

To reserve an item, find the item you want and click “Request”.
• Users will be notified by email when the item(s) is ready for pick-up.
• All requested items should be collected personally at the Desk (level 2).
• Requested items will be kept for 5 working days, after which, the items will be shelved or given to the next person who has requested the same item.
• To cancel a request, please use My Library Account.

Requests are triggered for items that are currently on loan, i.e., borrowed by another user. You will be notified by email when the requested item has been returned and is ready for pick up.  
If an item you have borrowed has been requested by another user, you will receive an email notification from the Library to return the item.

What are call numbers? How do I interpret them?

At SMU Libraries, all library materials are labelled with a call number on the spine (or cover).

Purpose of the call number: 
-To enable users to easily locate the item on shelf
-To group library items by subject

SMU Libraries uses the Library of Congress Classification (LCC) schemes <https://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcc.html> for our call numbers. To know more about LCC schedules, please visit Library of Congress website <http://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/lcco.html>.

 

Reading Library of Congress (LC) call numbers:
Components of a call number:

Arrangement of library materials in ascending order based on call numbers:
HC29 INT 2002	comes before the below because 'C' before 'D'
HD28 AD	comes before the below because '0' (i.e. 28 = 28.0) comes before '1'
HD28.15 KEL	comes before the below because '1' comes before '6'
HD28.6 ETM 1993

What are electronic resources?

Electronic resources (or e-resources) are materials in digital format accessible electronically.

Examples of e-resources are electronic journals (e-journal), electronic books (e-book) online databases in varied digital formats, Adobe Acrobat documents (.pdf), WebPages (.htm, .html, .asp etc) and more.

The Library Proxy Service enables remote access to e-resources off-campus.

Due to licensing agreement regulations, only SMU faculty, students and staff can access library e-resources.

How do I check legal abbreviations or the full name of a legal journal?

Abbreviations are used when citing cases and journal articles.If you only have part of the name, or just the abbreviation, you can obtain the full name by doing a search in the Cardiff Index to Legal Abbreviations <http://www.legalabbrevs.cardiff.ac.uk/>. 

Cardiff Index to Legal Abbreviations <http://www.legalabbrevs.cardiff.ac.uk/> is a free website which allows users to search by title or abbreviation.

Alternatively you can look up the abbreviation using the book Index to Legal Citations and Abbreviations  <http://search.library.smu.edu.sg/SMU:BooksandVideos:SMU_ALMA2137381420002601>by Donald Raistrick.
